Title:
Guava Black Spot New Disease Caused by Phyllosticta
Capitalensis isolate novel and their Characterization in Egypt
Keywords:
guava black spot, Phyllosticta capitalensis, Guignardia
mangiferae, postharvest diseases
Abstract:
During 2015-2017 seasons, guava fruit (Psidium guajava L.)
cv. White Balady, was found black spot novel symptoms, during
postharvest diseases survey in El-Kharga city (25.4390 N, 30.5586 E),
New Valley governorate- Egypt. Visible symptoms of the disease on guava
fruit showed sunken lesions with concentric development, variation in
colour ranging from greenish black to black and spread on severity
affected fruit. Naturally infected of guava fruit collected separately
in polyethylene bags from different local markets in El-Kharga city, at
green-yellow and yellow mature stage and transferred to the laboratory
for isolation and identification of pathogenic fungus. Tissues of guava
fruit spot were used to isolate the causal fungus. The fungus on potato
dextrose agar (PDA) medium was characterized by initially grey and
turned black with mature. To perform the phylogenetic analysis, the
internal transcribed spacer (ITS) region was amplified by PCR. To
amplify the ITS, the primer ITS-1 (5’-TCC GTA GGT GAA CCT GCG G-3’) and
reverse primer ITS-4 (5’-TCC TCC GCT TAT TGA TAT GC-3’) were used to
amplify rDNA-ITS regions of the fungus. The fungus was identified by
molecular analysis as Phyllosticta capitalensis isolate ARAFAT-GF5
according to the GenBank (Accession number- LC269950.1; GI: 119461242)
with synonym: Guignardia mangiferae. The isolate ARAFAT-GF5 (626 bp) was
used and the BLAST search program was used to search for nucleotide
sequence homology in GenBank. The sequence manipulation suite was useful
to attain the random coding, codon plot, coding usage and DNA stats.
Pathogenicity test was performed to complete Kochs postulates. Typical
black spot symptoms developed, and the pathogen was recovered from
inoculated fruit after 15 days and found as P. capitalensis. This is the
first report of Phyllosticta capitalensis from guava fruits in Egypt.
The results presented here may enable enhancements in the program of
integrated disease management.
